awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Understanding Multiphase Atmospheric Aerosol Particle Thermodynamics using Models, Mimics, and Microfluidics
awd_abstract_narration:
This effort will improve the ability to model aerosol properties in the atmosphere. It combines thermodynamic modeling and experimental studies to better understand water uptake by particles and the interactions of gases, solid and liquid aerosols, and water in the Earth's atmosphere.  Project results will benefit climate and air quality models and improve our ability to predict ambient concentrations of particulate matter.

The specific project outcomes expected are: (1) a parameterized predictive model for equilibrium internal structure of atmospheric aerosol particles (internally mixed, nodule, or core-shell) in complex multicomponent systems across the entire range of particle liquid water content or gas phase relative humidity; and (2) a novel microfluidic platform for mimicking and investigating aqueous-organic and aqueous-vapor interfaces which will yield valuable data for improving the parameterizations used in predictive models.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:  Thermodynamic predictions and measurements of aqueous solutions across the full range of relative humidities are essential for accurate determination of atmospheric aerosol particle microphysical properties and processes. The work has resulted in improved predictive modeling of aerosol particle thermodynamic properties, by developing and integrating (1) analytic advances in multilayer adsorption isotherm modeling with (2) experimental advances using two-phase microfluidic platforms. Models were developed and applied to predict solute activity (aerosol bulk) and surface tension (aerosol surfaces) for multicomponent aqueous solutions, using a unified framework, over the complete range of relative humidities. We then used our modeling framework in collaboration with experimental groups to support single particle measurements, particularly at high solute concentrations, to determine droplet pH, viscosity, hygroscopicity, and surface tensions. Complementary single-droplet measurements were also performed by our group using two-phase microfluidic platforms. For example, our group used microfluidic wells to study liquid-liquid phase separation in aqueous droplet as a function of water activity, to improve understanding of changes in internal structure observed in secondary organic aerosols. Overall, this work resulted in 18 publications to date, including a feature article in Journal of Physical Chemistry A and a review article in Aerosol Science and Technology.  

Broader Impact: PI and team members actively participated in annual Energy and U live performances.  Energy and U uses exciting demonstrations to teach the first law of thermodynamics to thousands of grade school students in the Twin Cities metro area each year. In addition, the PI designed and presented an AAAR tutorial entitled “Aerosol Measurements with Microfluidics”, including hands on demonstration of microfluidic flows.  We also published a review introducing the aerosol science community to the broad range of tools and platforms available on microfluidic platforms for use in aerosol science measurements and technologies.  The PI served as an instructor for the University of Minnesota Aerosol and Particle Measurement Short Course, lecturing on “Relative Humidity Effects on Aerosols” to an audience primarily composed of people from filtration industry. Finally, the modeling and microfluidic platforms developed here has enabled impact and new collaborative research in other applications and disciplines, including sea spray aerosols, agricultural sprays, liquid and solid separations, and fire-fighting foams.  


Last Modified: 07/07/2022
Modified by: Cari S Dutcher

Intellectual Merit:  Thermodynamic predictions and measurements of aqueous solutions across the full range of relative humidities are essential for accurate determination of atmospheric aerosol particle microphysical properties and processes. The work has resulted in improved predictive modeling of aerosol particle thermodynamic properties, by developing and integrating (1) analytic advances in multilayer adsorption isotherm modeling with (2) experimental advances using two-phase microfluidic platforms. Models were developed and applied to predict solute activity (aerosol bulk) and surface tension (aerosol surfaces) for multicomponent aqueous solutions, using a unified framework, over the complete range of relative humidities. Complementary single-droplet measurements were also performed by our group using two-phase microfluidic platforms. For example, our group used microfluidic wells to study liquid-liquid phase separation in aqueous droplet as a function of water activity, to improve understanding of changes in internal structure observed in secondary organic aerosols. Overall, this work resulted in 18 publications to date, including a feature article in Journal of Physical Chemistry A and a review article in Aerosol Science and Technology.  

Broader Impact: PI and team members actively participated in annual Energy and U live performances.  Energy and U uses exciting demonstrations to teach the first law of thermodynamics to thousands of grade school students in the Twin Cities metro area each year. In addition, the PI designed and presented an AAAR tutorial entitled "Aerosol Measurements with Microfluidics", including hands on demonstration of microfluidic flows. The PI served as an instructor for the University of Minnesota Aerosol and Particle Measurement Short Course, lecturing on "Relative Humidity Effects on Aerosols" to an audience primarily composed of people from filtration industry. Finally, the modeling and microfluidic platforms developed here has enabled impact and new collaborative research in other applications and disciplines, including sea spray aerosols, agricultural sprays, liquid and solid separations, and fire-fighting foams.
